articles.headline: Bose’s Latest Headphones Can Quell the Clangor
articles.snippet: The QuietComfort 15 model from Bose is state-of-the-art when it comes to noise-canceling headphones.
articles.abstract: The QuietComfort 15 model from Bose is state-of-the-art when it comes to noise-canceling headphones.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Sleigh bells ring, are you list’nin’?” “Strike the harp and join the chorus!” “What a bright time, it’s the right time, to rock the night away!” “Yuletide carols being sung by a choir,” “Just hear those sleigh bells jingling, ring-ting-tingling, too!” “Shall I play for you, pa-rum-pum-pum-pum, on my drum?” “The cattle are lowing  the poor baby wakes.”

articles.headline: Senator Moves to Hold Up Bernanke Confirmation
articles.snippet: The move is unlikely to derail Ben S. Bernanke’s reappointment as chairman of the Federal Reserve, but it could give the Fed’s critics more time to press their case.
articles.abstract: The move is unlikely to derail Ben S. Bernanke’s reappointment as chairman of the Federal Reserve, but it could give the Fed’s critics more time to press their case.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator Bernard Sanders of Vermont said on Wednesday that he would try to block the Senate from confirming Ben S. Bernanke to a second term as chairman of the Federal Reserve.

articles.headline: Something to Read
articles.snippet: For anyone considering an e-reader purchase this holiday season, here’s a roundup of current and soon-to-be-available devices.
articles.abstract: For anyone considering an e-reader purchase this holiday season, here’s a roundup of current and soon-to-be-available devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Amazon.com introduced its Kindle electronic book reader two years ago, the chief executive, Jeff Bezos, hoped the company was forever transforming the reading experience. The Kindle wasn’t the first e-reader on the market, but it came with a built-in advantage: a wireless connection to Amazon’s vast online bookstore. Today, when we think of e-readers, the Kindle comes readily to mind.

articles.headline: Leverage and Ambition Put Dubai in a Tailspin
articles.snippet: As Dubai prepares for weeks of arduous negotiations with creditors over restructuring Dubai World’s debt, outsiders still do not know what to make of the situation.
articles.abstract: As Dubai prepares for weeks of arduous negotiations with creditors over restructuring Dubai World’s debt, outsiders still do not know what to make of the situation.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  What’s the difference between Dubai and Dubai World?

articles.headline: Sounds to Fill a Music Lover’s Life
articles.snippet: These products are worth considering for an innovative gift this year.
articles.abstract: These products are worth considering for an innovative gift this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMERICANS love their flat panel TVs, thanks to the great picture quality. But fewer people get worked up over a good pair of speakers. With audio, out of sight is often out of mind.

articles.headline: Move to Repay Aid Helps Bank of America Shed Stigma
articles.snippet: The plan to repay $45 billion in federal aid should help the bank recruit a new chief executive by freeing it from Treasury restrictions on executive pay.
articles.abstract: The plan to repay $45 billion in federal aid should help the bank recruit a new chief executive by freeing it from Treasury restrictions on executive pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than a year after grasping two multibillion-dollar bailouts from Washington, a resurgent Bank of America announced on Wednesday that it would repay all of its federal aid, underscoring the banking industry’s swift recovery from the gravest financial crisis since the Depression.

articles.headline: Elusive Goal of Greening U.S. Energy
articles.snippet: Growth in clean energy industries and green jobs has been slower than anticipated, with some green-industry companies shedding jobs in the United States.
articles.abstract: Growth in clean energy industries and green jobs has been slower than anticipated, with some green-industry companies shedding jobs in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Great Green Hope for lifting America’s economy is not looking so robust.

articles.headline: Afghanistan Speech by Obama Wins Over Some Skeptics
articles.snippet: Opinions on the Afghan war remained diverse, but the president persuaded some people on both sides of the political aisle.
articles.abstract: Opinions on the Afghan war remained diverse, but the president persuaded some people on both sides of the political aisle.
articles.lead_paragraph: A month ago, Donnie Jones, a 40-year-old Republican who lives outside Dallas, told pollsters that he was not sure President Obama had a plan for the war in Afghanistan. But after hearing the president speak Tuesday night, Mr. Jones feels reassured that Mr. Obama not only has a plan, but also one he can generally support.

articles.headline: Black Caucus Seeks to Ease Radio’s Woes
articles.snippet: The caucus is pressuring the White House to address the way the financial crisis has hurt minority-owned businesses, most notably a troubled New York City-based broadcaster.
articles.abstract: The caucus is pressuring the White House to address the way the financial crisis has hurt minority-owned businesses, most notably a troubled New York City-based broadcaster.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The radio business has nothing to do with the plan to overhaul the nation’s system for regulating banks and other financial institutions.

articles.headline: In Secret Meetings, Comcast Wooed G.E. and Won NBC
articles.snippet: Code names and helicopters helped keep Comcast’s efforts to buy NBC from G.E. quiet.
articles.abstract: Code names and helicopters helped keep Comcast’s efforts to buy NBC from G.E. quiet.
articles.lead_paragraph: The secret meeting was set for an early July afternoon in a condominium along the ninth hole of a golf course in Sun Valley, Idaho. Jeffrey R. Immelt, General Electric’s chief executive, arrived first, taking care to avoid being spotted by his own employee, Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, who was mingling with other executives nearby.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Tim Arango

articles.headline: Bernanke Says Fed ‘Should Have Done More’
articles.snippet: Under fire from both parties, Ben S. Bernanke conceded that “I did not anticipate a crisis of this magnitude.”
articles.abstract: Under fire from both parties, Ben S. Bernanke conceded that “I did not anticipate a crisis of this magnitude.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Under fire from Democrats and Republicans alike, Ben S. Bernanke on Thursday defended his record as chairman of the Federal Reserve but conceded that the central bank’s lapses contributed to the financial crisis.
